Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Gravity at the Micron Scale with Laser-Cooled Trapped Microspheres
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity is the least understood fundamental force of nature - there is a 16 order of magnitude disparity between the energy scale of quantum gravity and that of the other Standard Model (electro-weak) forces. The mystery can be cast in another way: why is gravity so much weaker than the other Standard Model forces? This award funds research on the characteristics of gravity at sub-millimeter distances to be conducted through the use of cryogenic micro-cantilever beams which allow measurements of gravitational forces at sub-100 micron length scales at the atto-Newton level. The force sensitivity of these micro-cantilever experiments is limited by mechanical dissipation. To mitigate this mechanical loss, we will develop a novel apparatus to trap and cool dielectric nanospheres using lasers. By optically levitating the force sensor, an exquisite decoupling from the environment is possible.

Studies such as ours could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond the Standard Model which has recently been famously validated by the detection of what appears to be the Higgs boson. Our research program is at the forefront of current knowledge and enhances the scientific competency of the state of Nevada, which is currently under-represented in terms of scientific endeavor. Additional efforts are undertaken to bring this exciting research to the general university population through a series of scheduled lectures for incoming college freshmen interested in the sciences. Also, public lectures are presented to encourage young people in Nevada to pursue career in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

There is a vast 16 order of magnitude disparity between the apparent energy scale of quantum gravity and that of the other known forces in Nature. Theoretically, this necessitates an extreme fine-tuning of parameters in the Standard Model of particle physics in order to explain the physically observed value of the Higgs mass. The most popular theoretical solution to this puzzle is supersymmetry, currently being searched for at the Large Hadron Collider. However, as a number of recent theories have suggested, important clues related to this ``hierarchy problem'' can be obtained in tabletop, low-energy experiments, by measuring how gravity behaves at sub-millimeter distances. Such measurements could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond the Standard Model, in the form of gravitational inverse square law (ISL) violations at short-range. However, the gravitational force between massive objects becomes weak very rapidly as their size and separation distance decreases, thus making ultra-sensitive measurements a necessity at these length scales.  The best experimental constraints to date on such ISL violations at length scales between 1mm and 1um come from precision torsion balance experiments,  sensitive micro-cantilever measurements, and investigations of the Casimir effect.

 In this project we have studied the viability of another type of sensor which could be useful for measurements of gravity at the micron scale, namely optically levitated dielectric microspheres. By optically levitating the force sensor, an exquisite decoupling from the environment is possible, yielding sub-aN force sensitivity at room temperature. This new technique could ultimately advance our understanding of gravity at the micron length scale by many orders of magnitude. In order to attain such sensitivity it is imperative to operate in the high vacuum regime. However the particles are initially loaded into an optical trap under low-vacuum conditions to provide damping during the loading process. It has been a challenge for this community to obtain robust methods of maintaining trapped particles while transitioning into high vacuum.  In this project period, we have established a set of trapping and cooling conditions which allow pumping microspheres through the intermediate vacuum region where instabilities are known to be present.  In particular we have identified these instabilities as being due to the radiometric force, and have developed a robust strategy to avoid them.

At high vacuum we have demonstrated sub-attonewton sensitivity with lifetimes exceeding days, which should be sufficient sensitivity for improved measurements of gravity at the micron scale by at least 3 orders of magnitude. We estimate that ten times further improved sensitivity can be attained with reduced laser noise at similar pressures. Our method produces trapped beads with zero or negative charge, which remains constant over the trap lifetime at high vacuum. Thus this system shows promise for precision measurements in ultrahigh vacuum requiring long averaging times, including tests of short-range gravitational forces or Casimir forces, as well as experiments on quantum optomechanics.

The sensitivity achieved exceeds that of any conventional room-temperature solid-state force sensor by over an order of magnitude. We are able to calibrate the force sensitivity by applying a known electric field to a charged bead with one or two excess electrons. If a particle is confined at the antinodes of an optical standing wave, by studying the motion of a particle which has been moved to an adjacent trapping site, the known spacing of the antinodes can also be used to calibrate the displacement spectrum of the particle.  This work has resulted in 8 publications in refereed journals, and 30 presentations (10 invited, 20 contributed) at conferences, workshops, universities and national labs.  The next steps in the experiment are final assembly of the source mass and its driving mechanism, and investigation of systematic errors in preliminary gravity measurements.

Broader Impact:

One PhD Thesis and one Master's Thesis were supported by this award.  Four undergraduate Senior theses were supported by this award.  One postdoctoral scholar was supported by this award.  This award also provided partial support of two graduate research assistants and one undergraduate researcher.  The students working on this project learned valuable techniques which make them attractive future members of the scientific workforce. Their training included optics, vacuum technology, lasers, computer-aided design and modeling, nanofabrication, electronics, data acquisition, and data analysis. The technology being developed in this project will have other impacts in the general area of precision force sensing.  In addition to tests of gravitational physics at short length scales, such technology may also be useful for gravitational wave detection, magnetic field sensing, electric field sensing, or inertial sensing. For example, a former PhD student has begun work towards commercialization of a force sensing technique based on similar technology.
